div.p: Most of the significant work has been sunimarized in a number of reviews and articles. In these there ~i'us, of necessity, a good deal of simplification and omission of detail. . . . With the passage of time, even 1,find nij7seIf' accepting such .rimpl$ied accounts.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: I had the good fortune to arrive in the laboratory of Gobind Khorana, in September 1956, just one month after he had made the accidental discovery of the phosphodiester method for the chemical synthesis of deoxyribooligonucleotides,[21 a synthetic approach whose full exploitation led to elucidation of the genetic code and the first total synthesis of a gene.r3-51 An identifying characteristic of the Khorana approach to the production of synthetic polynucleotides for the solution of biological problems has been a willingness to use both chemical and enzymatic tools as appropriate, [53 61 and this catholic approach is the foundation of all the molecular technology employed in modern molecular genetics." -91 It had a major impact on my thinking.

During my post-doctoral time in the Khorana group 1 was mainly involved in small molecule synthesis : nucleoside-5' triphosphatesrl" and nucleoside-3',5' cyclic However, I was able to contribute to the technology of polynucleotide synthesis by the development of the methoxytrityl series of 5'-hydroxyl protecting groups" and with a first approach to the chemical synthesis of ribooligonucleotides." 3' In 1961 I left the Khorana group to join the Fisheries Research Board of Canada Vancouver Laboratory. Whilst much of my research effort was directed at studies on salmonid physiology and endocrinology, it was possible to continue studies on the chemistry of phosphodiester synthesis, and this resulted in a new method for nucleoside-3'5' cyclic phosphate synthesis by alkaline transesterificatior m d e r anhydrous conditions, a reaction which obviated the need for chemical protecting groups on the heterocyclic bases."4.

In 1966, 1 became a faculty member in the Department of Biochemistry of the University of British Columbia, which has been my academic home ever since. Studies on oligonucleotide [**I Copyright ' The Nobel Foundation 1'9'94. We thank the Nobel Foundation.

Stockholm. for permission to print this lecture. synthesis continued, directed at the reaction of deoxyribonucleoside phosphorofluoridates in anhydrous alkaline conditions.[ '61 Although this method, in making base protecting groups redundant. represented a significant advance, it did not have the generality required of a universal synthetic method." 7 . I * ]

An approach to deoxyribooligonucleotide synthesis that did prove to be versatile, simple, and useful, although inefficient. involved the extension of short primers using E. coli polynucleotide phosphorylase, in the presence of Mn2+ and NaCI, with deoxyribonucleoside-5' diphosphates as substrate. ["-22] This procedure. which made possible the synthesis of deoxyribooligonucleotides up to 12 to 13 nucleotides in length, proved to be a significant breakthrough for our small group, because it allowed us to undertake a number of fairly ambitious molecular biological projects at a time (between 1970 and 1980) when oligonucleotides were not generally accessible. Of course. it has been displaced as a routine synthetic procedure with the advent of automated chemical synthesis (which still uses the methoxytrityl protecting group) with nucleoside-3' phosphoroamidites as the key intermediate^.['^ -2 s 1

div.head: Model Studies on Oligonucleotide Double Helix Stability and Specificity
div.p: In 1968 planned studies on the biosynthesis of salmonid prot-aminer261 and on the sequence of dA,dT-rich crab DNAcz7] became impossible for personal or for technical reasons. Casting around for a new project, I suggested to Caroline Astell. who was studying for her Ph.D, a series of model studies with chemically synthesized oligonucleotides directed at defining the stability and specificity of oligonucleotide duplexes of defined sequence. The objective was to see if a synthetically accessible oligonucleotide could be a tool for identifying and isolating a specific messenger RNA based on Watson -Crick hydrogen bonding. From the statistical point of view it should be possible, since the length required of an oligonucleotide in order for it to be unique in a given genome size ranges from 9 nucleotides for h phages with a genome of 4.6 x lo4 base pairs to 18 for the higher plants, such as A . cepa with a genome of 1.5 x 10'" base pairs (Table 1). Also relevant was the work of Michelson and Monny["' and of Niyogi and Thomasr291 on interactions of ribooligonucleotides with ribopolynucleotides. which indicated that stable double helices can be formed with as few as seven base pairs and. equally importantly, which demonstrated that

Table I . DNA content of haploid genomes and oligonucleotide length required for unique recognition [a] Organism Z [b] N [ c ] Organism Z "Jl N [cl Viruses Plants h-Phage 4 . 6 ~ 10' 9 C. reinhardti; 10' 14 Bacteria A . thU[iRnU 108 14 D /in~~uriiiiiriu' I . 7 x 10' 1 1 Z. inu)..y 6 . 6 ~1 0 ~ 17 E. mli 4 1 x 1 0 ' 12 A . cepu 1 . 5 ~1 0 ' ~ 18 Fungi Animals s l,rf,L~;.siLil, I .I x 1 0' I 3 c. e1egun.s 108 14 N. ('ruissu 2.1 x107 13 D. nielunogaster 1.3 x Jon 14 B. rerio 10' 16 M . muscu1u.s 2 . 2 ~1 0 ' 17 H. supiens 3.3x109 17 [a] Recognition by the nucleotide is unique when 4' 2 2 x Z. [b] Z = the number of base pairs in the genome. [c] N = number of nucleotides in the oligonucleotide.
there is a significant increase in duplex stability for each additional base pair up to about 16 base pairs (Fig. 1).

The work of Gilham et al. with random length oligothymidylates covalently attached to cellulose demonstrated their potential power for affinity chromat~graphy,[~'. 311 which led to a n important procedure for isolation of eukaryote ~R N A S . [ ' ~~ However, although data was available on duplex stability involving mixtures of oligonucleotides of defined length with DNA,[33, 341 there was I 70!
no systematic data obtained with pure oligonucleotides of defined sequence and length.

Our approach was to prepare deoxyribooligonucleotide celluloses by using simple oligonucleotides of defined length and sequence synthesized by the Khorana method and to employ these oligonucleotide celluloses, in the form of thermally eluted columns, to establish the stability of duplexes with a variety of complementary, or partially complementary, deoxyribo-and ribooligon~cleotides.[~ -381 The results and conclusions of this time-consuming but critical series of experiments has been summarized in more detail and only some highlights will be discussed here.

First, it was clear that, under appropriate conditions of ionic strength, stable duplexes containing as few as six dA-dT base pairs can be formed (Fig. 2). Further, additional base pairs increase duplex stability significantly, but in a nonlinear manner; the incremental increase in stability diminishes with increased length. Also, a single base-pair mismatch of dT with dT or of dT with d G decreases duplex stability by the same amount (equivalent to removing about two base pairs), but duplex formation is still possible at low temperature (Fig. 2). In addition, it was obvious that oligonucleotide duplexes form rapidly at low temperatures, conditions under which denatured double-strand D N A does not reanneal. These experiments convinced me that it would be possible to use a synthetic oligonucleotide to identify an R N A or a DNA containing the exact Watson-Crick complement of its sequence and to differentiate it from similar but not identical sequences. An opportunity to demonstrate this principle was provided by mutants in the lysozyme-encoding locus of phage T4.[40' Also, at a later date, the data made me realize that it should be possible to use short synthetic deoxyribooligonucleotides as specific mutagens and to differentiate between a point mutant and wildtype DNA.

Experiments on the interaction of deoxyribooligonucleotide celluloses and ribooligonucleotides confirmed the results of earlier studies on the relative stabilities of DNA-DNA and DNA-RNA double strand^.'^^.^^^ They also demon- base pair is relatively stable (Fig. 3). Differences in the stability of dT. d G and dT, rG base pairs (compare Figs. 2 and 3), presumably, reflect differences in the base pairing allowed in the B forms and the A forms of double helix.[4z1 The observation has two practical implications. First. the most specific and stringent interaction of an oligonucleotide probe will be the one between a deoxyribooligonucleotide and DNA. Second, one cannot assume that duplex structures that are formed by RNA will be formed by DNA or by deoxyribooligonucleotides. In connection with this. I have always been puzzled by the widespread acceptance of the idea that deoxyinosine is precocious in base pairing because inosine behaves in a precocious manner in tRNA duplex interactions. Studies on deoxyinosine. in fact, indicate that it fLinctions as a specific analog of deoxyguanosine, although it does not self-aggregate as does deoxyguanosine.r'. 8,421 30i N,' __c The above empirical studies and related ones not discussed here[391 provided the direct inspiration for and commitment to our use of synthetic deoxyribooligonucleotides as probes for isolation of specific DNA fragments, as primers for the direct sequencing of double-stranded DNA, a 5 primers for precise definition of the ends of mRNAs, as specific mutagens, and as tools for the identification and isolation of point mutations.

div.head: Deoxyribooligonucleotides as DNA Probes
div.p: When the model studies described in the foregoing section were commenced, in 1968, the intent was to develop a method for isolation of specific mRNAs by affinity chromatography. However, the development of the full panoply of DNA cloning techniques in the early 1970s["] made it clear that the prime target for work with synthetic deoxyribooligonucleotides should be a method for monitoring gene isolation. Discussions with Dr. Benjamin D. Hall made me aware of the important studies of F. Sherman on double-frameshift mutants of yeast cytochrome ~,.[""l Knowledge of the amino acid sequence of these mutants allowed the unambiguous prediction of the N-terminal coding sequence and, hence. provided a specific target for an oligonucleotide of defined sequence. A second attractive feature about a yeast gene as a first target was the fact that the length of oligonucleotide required for a specific probe (13 nucleotides. Table 1 )was close to the limit for our enzymatic method of synthesis.['". r 1 . 2 2 1 The required probe was synthesized by means of the enzymatic method'"'] and was used to isolate the gene, albeit with some difficulty.["h1 thus clearly validating the principle that a synthetic oligonucleotide could function as a probe for gene isolation. The subsequent generalization of the method using mixtures of o l i g o n ~c ~e o t i d e s [ " ~~" ~' has made this approach to gene isolation into a powerful tool in molecular genetics.['. ' 1

div.head: Sequencing Double-Stranded DNA with Oligonucleotide Primers
div.p: At the time when the iso-I-cytochrome c gene was isolated, the chemical method for DNA sequence determination[""] and the chain terminating enzymatic method[501 had newly been developed: the former is applicable to double-stranded DNA and the latter to single-stranded DNA. The sequences of the ends of the Eco RI-Hind 111 DNA fragment containing the cytochrome c coding sequence were obtained by the chemical method.["'] Based on my conviction that an oligonucleotide should hybridize ur loit, retnperuturr with a complementary DNA strand of a denatured DNA double helix in solution, even though the second DNA strand was present and capable of producing a thermodynamically much more stable structure, I decided to investigate the possibility of directly sequencing double-stranded DNA by the enzymatic method with synthetic oligonucleotide primers. The critical question was whether the second DNA strand would displace a short oligonucleotide from a complex with the complementary DNA strand under the conditions of the Sanger enzymatic sequencing method.[s Thc first experiment was completely successful, an enormously excit-

div.head: REVIEWS
div.p: ing event. As a consequence, the sequence of the gene was completed b? "walking" along the sequence with a series of short oligonucleotide primers nine or ten nucleotides in length.[521 I believe that the full potential of this approach to gene sequencing has yet to be realized.

Another important application of oligonucleotide-primed sequencing of double-stranded DNA is the precise identification of point mutations produced by classical genetic techniques at a given locus. A particular good example was in the analysis of a large number of independently isolated point mutations in a yeast suppressor tRNA gene.r53. 541

div.head: Defining the Ends of mRNAs Precisely
div.p: It is important to define the sequences at the 5'and 3'-ends of mRNAs exactly. For the 3'-end of an mRNA, this can be done by oligonucleotide-primed sequencing with reverse transcriptase for the Sanger sequencing method with RNA enriched for the desired mRNA as template. The family of 12 deoxyribooligonucleotides consisting of a tract of dT residues terminated at the 3'-end by two other deoxyribonucleotides can be annealed to the 3'-end of polyladenylated eukaryotic mRNA. If the transcribed sequence has a unique 3'-end, only one of the twelve oligonucleotides should act as a specific primer. This strategy was used to define the sequence of the unique 3'-end of bovine growth hormone mRNA[551 and to demonstrate and precisely define the microheterogeneity at the 3'-end of the bovine prolactin niRNA transcript.[561 The iso-I -cytochrome c proved to have a unique 3'-end,[571 while the 5'-end of the same mRNA is very disperse indeed. as was shown by oligonucleotide primed extension using the mRNA as template.[581 There are no other methods for defining the 5'and 3'-ends of mRNAs with this precision. ii degree of precision that is essential to the accurate definition of transcription initiation and termination sigilals.[5'.

div.head: Oligonucleotide-Directed Mutagenesis
div.p: I .strong[,. believe thut, through the products of organic synthesis, it will be possible to gain influence o w r the tirvelopnient of organisriis and to produce changes thut .vurpus.v (ill that cun be uchieved bq' conventional breeding.

Emil Fischer[s91 ''Tlic. ignis fatuus of Genetics has been the specific mutagen, tlie reagent that would penetrate to a given gene, recognize it, and modifi' it in an specifk-ISUJ..'' J. Lederbergihol Initiation of the project to isolate the yeast cytochrome c gene made me realize that 1 needed to learn about D N A sequence determination. I was lucky to be able to spend a year, starting in the fall of 1975, in Fred Sanger's laboratory working with the "plus-minus'' sequencing method as part of the team that was attacking the sequence of the E. coli phage @X174. [6'.621 There are three pairs of overlapping genes in the 5386 nucleotide All genes are encoded on the same DNA strand, and each overlapping pair uses different codon reading frames. An essential integral component of defining the position and reading frame of these genes was the availability of nonsense mutants suppressible by amber or ochre suppressors. This use of precisely located mutants of a particular phenotype highlighted the need for a very specific mutagenic method that would define the target to a specific base pair in the genome and introduce a predetermined change with sufficiently high efficiency to allow genomic screening in order to identify phenotypically silent mutants. Since the DNA of phage @XI 74 is single stranded and the complete sequence of its genome was known from our earlier studies, the demonstration that small oligonucleotides as short as seven nucleotides in length could form stable duplexes at low temperature even with a mismatch (Fig. 2) suggested that oligonucleotide-directed mutagenesis should be possible. There was additional useful information : Point mutants can be reverted, albeit with low efficiency, by annealing mutant phage @XI74 D N A with fragments from the complementary strand of wildtype D N A prior to transfection.[66. 671 However, fragments very much longer than those that we could readily synthesize were needed. and the low efficiency precluded genotypic screening.[". 671 In discussing these issues, Clyde Hutchison (who. also was spending one year in Fred Sanger's group and whose biological knowledge of @XI74 was invaluable to the sequencing project) and I realized that the studies of Kornberg and Gouprovided an obvious route to a mutagenic method, since they had demonstrated that an oligonucleotide as short as nine nucleotides in length could act as a primer for E. coli DNA polymerase I on a circular single-strand template, and that the product could be converted into a closed circular duplex by enzymatic ligation. It was also known that most of the primer molecule is excised from the product,[721 presumably due to the 5'-exonuclease activity of E. coli DNA polymerase I,["] With this information and our knowledge that the stability of duplexes involves a mismatched oligonucleotide, we decided to use a 12 nucleotide oligomer, with a centrally positioned single nucleotide mismatch, as primer and with (DX 174 DNA as template and E. coli D N A polymerase I in which the 5'-exonuclease had been inactivated by subtilisin [73 751 to construct a closed. circular, double-stranded DNA with the oligonucleotide in one strand. Transfection of E. coli with this DNA should produce wild-type and mutant phage. The specific inutatioiis chosen for the first experiment were the production and reversion of a known nonsense mutation am3 in the lytic function. gene E, of @X174, since convenient phenotypic screens for these mutations were available. The mutations involved the interconversion of a

div.head: Trp codon TGG and an amber codon TAG by G -T and A-C
div.p: In the first experiments. mutation was achieved but at low efficiency. This was increased to a very encouraging level of about 3 5 ' / o after removal of incompletely closed duplexes by adsorption to nitrocellulose or treatment with a singlestrand specific nuclease under conditions in which a single basepair mismatch was not degraded.[761 Further studies directed at optimizing the mutagenic conditions resulted in efficiencies of up to 39 YO with a 12 nucleotide mutagenic primer and significant mutation with a heptamer mutagenic primer.[771 The wisdom of using subtilisin-treated DNA polymerase is evident from comparison of these results with those of another study which employed intact E. coli DNA polymerase I.[''] lian, [43. Further studies on the mutagenesis of phage (DX174 demonstrated that, in addition to the two transition mutations of the first experiments, it was possible to produce transversion mutations and single nucleotide deletions, also by using very short oligonucleotide^.[^^] Clearly, the method was highly specific, efficient, and general within the context of the genome of QX174. It was time to generalize the method further so that it could be applied to any cloned fragment of DNA. The icosahedral bacteriophages, such as QX174, are not potential vectors for recombinant DNA because the amount of DNA that can be accommodated in the viral particle is limited. The filamentous bacteriophages, on the other hand, can accommodate additional DNA incorporated into the genome. At the time when Mark Zoller and I were planning the generalization of the method, there were those that argued in favor of a methodology applied to double-stranded recombinant plasmids. It seemed to us that the biology of a filamentous bacteriophage, which produces single-stranded, circular DNA and then purifies it as phage particles, argued overpoweringly in favor of phage DNA as vector. Subsequent developments in recombinant phage biology and in the construction of phagemids". ' I have vindicated this strategic decision, although viable procedures for plasmid mutagenesis are available.[8n "I Oligonucleotide mutagenesis with filamentous phage DNA as template proved to be more difficult than with QX174 DNA, presumably because of a greater degree of secondary structure that inhibited the production of fulllength, double-stranded circles. Consequently, new procedures for enhancing the efficiency of the mutagenic procedure had to be d e ~e l o p e d . [ ' ~-' ~~

The power of the methodology was graphically illustrated by our first involvement in protein engineering in collaboration with Greg Winter and Alan Fersht.la7I This, of course, presaged the enormous use of the methodology in protein structure-function analysis that has become a feature of modern biochemistry.

div.head: Genotypic Selection or Screening for Mutants
div.p: Because the immediate product of the enzymatic incorporation of a mutagenic oligonucleotide into a double-stranded recombinant DNA is a heteroduplex, biological replication of the D N A will produce mutated and unmutated progeny DNAs, providing there is no asymmetry in the mechanism of DNA replication or providing there is not an asymmetric mismatchrepair mechanism. In fact, it is possible to achieve mutagenic efficiencies of close to 50% by using standard procedures[77. 8 5 1 With this level of efficiency, screening by DNA sequence determination is the most effective procedure for detecting the desired mutant DNA. However, often the yield of mutant is considerably less than 50%. It is my opinion that the predominant reason for this is the use of template D N A that is contaminated with random oligonucleotides resulting from bacterial DNA degradation; others ascribe it to biological mismatch-repair favoring the sequence of the template DNA.[801 Whatever the cause of the reduced yield of mutant, procedures other than sequence determination are required for mutant identification. The ones that are available fall into two categories: those using the mutagenic oligonucleotide as a tool for identifying mutant DNA and those which select for progeny derived from the newly synthesized, oligonucleotide-containing DNA strand.

The significantly enhanced stability of a perfectly matched oligonucleotide duplex relative to one with a mismatch (see Fig. 2) suggested that a mutagenic oligonucleotide should be able to identify mutant complementary DNA. This principle was used to develop a method for selection of mutant DNA. In this procedure the mixture of wild-type and mutant singlestranded phage DNA produced by oligonucleotide mutagenesis acts as a template for double-stranded DNA synthesis with the mutagenic oligonucleotide as primer under conditions that should not form a mismatched duplex.[881 Following transfection into E. coli, this procedure can select mutant DNA with close to 100% efficiency.

An alternative procedure is to use the mutagenic oligonucleotide as a probe to screen for mutant DNA in plaques produced by E. coli with mutagenized phage. [83. 841 Again, this procedure is very reliable in the identification of mutant DNA. The same principle is used in the identification of point mutations in human DNA[*'] where, of course, the complexity of the human genome requires a probe containing a minimum of 17 nucleotides (see Table 1).

A number of procedures for selection of progeny derived from the DNA strand containing the mutagenic oligonucleotide have been developed.r8n1 Two of these, one based on in vivo selection and the other on in vitro selection have proved most popular and are widely used. In vivo selection involves a template DNA in which about 1 % of the deoxythymidine residues have been replaced by deoxyuridine residues. This template is incorporated into double-stranded DNA in which the mutagenic oligonucleotide is part of the in vitro synthesized second strand. On transfection of an appropriate E. coli host, the deoxyuridine strand is selectively degraded by the bacterium's DNA damage-repair system, resulting in progeny derived primarily from the mutant strand.[901 In vitro selection involves a normal recombinant phage template DNA with the mutagenic oligonucleotide incorporated in the second strand that contains enzymatically synthesized thiophosphate internucleotide linkages. These are resistant to cleavage by restriction endonuclease, which, as a consequence nicks the template. The nicked template is partially degraded with an exonuclease and then repaired by a D N A polymerase and D N A ligase. The result is a doublestranded DNA which, predominantly, is mutant in both strands and which produces, predominantly, mutant recombinant phage on transfection of E. ~o l i . ~~~~

div.head: Conclusion
div.p: This concludes my account of our studies on the use of synthetic deoxyribooligonucleotides as tools for characterizing naturally occurring nucleic acids, which is as accurate as I can make it, bearing in mind the caveat of Fred Sangerr'] cited at the beginning of this article. Clearly, many other applications of oligonucleotide in biology exist, notably the polymerase chain reaction['*] and its multitudinous variations, but also in doublestrand DNA synthesis and in the use of oligonucleotide probes in vitro and in vivo. In the latter area there is the potential for development of a whole new chemistry directed at pharmaceuti-cals that block the expression of specific genes and at diagnostic agents.["-q4'

With regard to our own work, it is very satisfying that the model studies started in 1968 provided the inspiration for so many applications and scientific collaborations (only a few of which are cited in this article). The potential of oligonucleotidedirected site-specific mutagenesis was apparent from the outset as confirmed by the following quote:

I 'This new method of niutagenesis hcis considerable potentirrl. . .to tl<fine the role o f . . . origins of DNA replication, promoters, arid the sequences .for ribosonze-building .sites , . . specfic rnutcition within protein structural genes . . . will allow precise studies ofprotein S I ruc t w e -,fun c t ion relu t ioizsh ips " Hutchison et al.L76] However. we could not have anticipated the explosion of gene isolations. the improvements in DNA sequence determination methodology, and the advances in the chemistry of nucleic acids synthesis that have occurred since 1978. This has resulted in an amazing increase in the use of site-directed mutagenesis as an analytical tool in biochemistry and biology. And it has been accompanied by continual improvements in the basic methodologies and versatility of site-directed mutagenesis["-' ' 1 and the initiation of new scientific publications such as Protein Engineering and Protein Science. It would not be too much of an exaggeration to say that the prediction of Emil Fischer in 1917rs"J has been fulfilled, and the dilemma posed by Joshua Lederberg in 1959[601 has been resolved. My c'areer in iiucleic acid research ioould not exist without the e.utmiple and inspiration of Gobind Kliorana. Also, I am indebted to the many young scientists $,tho have been nicnibers of' m ~' group over the pcist 30 years, hut especially to Caroline Astell, Shirlejs Gillam, Patricia Jahnke, and Mark Zoller, who rvei-e tlw indivicluals primarily responsible for the studies discussed in this article. as well as to Tom Atkinson who undertook the arduous task of manual chemical synthesis of oligonucleotides in the timr inzrnrdiarelj~ prior to the introduction of automated sjwthcsters. Two crucial, indispensiblc collaborators, whose hiologiccrl czpertise and commitment 1vere essenticil to these studies, IWWJ Bcw Huff in the sttiu'i~::>s on the isofation of ihe yeust c,vio-chroinc~ (~ gene mid Clyde Hutchison in the development of oligo-niicI~~otick.-dilectt~d mu tagenesis. And t n ~~ year in Fred Sanger ' . s 1aborcitor-i. tt'as wondwfid in its excitment and in its timcliness. Reseclrcli ,fiinding support h). the U.S. National Institures of Health IIUS essential in alloit'ing me to continue synthetic nucleotide chemistry in the years immediately crftcr I lef~ the Khorana group. Since 1966, the Medical Research Council of Canada has continuotis1.v provided me nxith the salary support and research grants that have been the stublc. aid very niucl? uppreciured,fourdation f o r in!' more speculative research activities. I have also received, ,for niore limired periods, research siipporr ,from the Briti.rh Columbia Health Research Foundation and, from the Natioiirrl Cancer Iristitute of Canada. For the past ,four years I have been Scirntific Leader ofthe Canadian Protein Engineering Net-~~' o r k of Centres of E.xcellence, a country-wide collaboration on protein structure~function analysis. generous1.v. funded by the Network of Ceritrcs of E.welle?zce program. Finally, firstly at the British Columbia Research Council, then at the Fisheries Research Board of' Canada Vancouver Laboratory, most!,! in the Department of Biochemistry and more recently in ihr Biotechnology Laboratory, the canipus o f t k e University of British Columbia has been n y scientific home since 1956. I am very grateful fbr the environment that it has provided, especially in the Department of' Biochemistry where the studies described in this article were carried out.

figure.figDesc: Fig. 1. The relationship between oligouridylate length and the Kx of double helices with polyadenylate in 0.02 M NaCI, 0.01 M sodium cacodylate (Me,As(O)O-Na'), pH 7.0 [ 2 8 ] . N = number ofuridine residues.

strated a further important principle: a dT, rG r Michael Smith, born in Blackpool, Great Britain, on April 26, 1932, studied Chemistry at the University ofManchester,from 1950 to 1953. HeJi'nished his Ph.D. there in 1956 with H . B. Henbest on cyclohexane diols and then joined the group of Gobincl Khorana in Vancouver, Canada, as Postdoctoral Fellow to work on biologically important organophosphates. In 1960 he moved with the group to the Institute for Enzyme Research at the University of Wisumsin and worked on the synthesis ofribooligonucleotides. In 1961 he accepted apost at the Fischerirs Research Board of Canada Laboratory in the grounds of the University of British Columbia in Vancouver. He was awarded the position of Medical Research Associate of the Medical Research Council of Canada at this university in 1966. A new interdisciplinary Institute, the Biotechnology Laboratory, came into being in 1986 with his help. After a lzeaq. load oj administrative tasks recently, he is looking,forward to returning to the bench.
